segment.source: Network security Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback (Windows 10)
segment.target: Network security Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Network security Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Network security Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback security policy setting.

segment.source: Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback
segment.target: Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, and security considerations for the Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback security policy setting.

segment.source: Reference
segment.target: Reference

segment.source: This policy affects session security during the authentication process between devices running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later and those devices running earlier versions of the Windows operating system.
segment.target: This policy affects session security during the authentication process between devices running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later and those devices running earlier versions of the Windows operating system.

segment.source: For computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later, services running as Local System require a service principal name (SPN) to generate the session key.
segment.target: For computers running Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7 and later, services running as Local System require a service principal name (SPN) to generate the session key.

segment.source: However, if Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM is set to disabled, services running as Local System will fall back to using NULL session authentication when they transmit data to servers running versions of Windows earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008.
segment.target: However, if Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM is set to disabled, services running as Local System will fall back to using NULL session authentication when they transmit data to servers running versions of Windows earlier than Windows Vista or Windows Server 2008.

segment.source: NULL session does not establish a unique session key for each authentication; and thus, it cannot provide integrity or confidentiality protection.
segment.target: NULL session does not establish a unique session key for each authentication; and thus, it cannot provide integrity or confidentiality protection.

segment.source: The setting Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback determines whether services that request the use of session security are allowed to perform signature or encryption functions with a well-known key for application compatibility.
segment.target: The setting Network security: Allow LocalSystem NULL session fallback determines whether services that request the use of session security are allowed to perform signature or encryption functions with a well-known key for application compatibility.

segment.source: Possible values
segment.target: Possible values

segment.source: Enabled
segment.target: Enabled

segment.source: When a service running as Local System connects with a NULL session, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection but allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.
segment.target: When a service running as Local System connects with a NULL session, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection but allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.

segment.source: This increases application compatibility, but it degrades the level of security.
segment.target: This increases application compatibility, but it degrades the level of security.

segment.source: Disabled
segment.target: Disabled

segment.source: When a service running as Local System connects with a NULL session, session security will be unavailable.
segment.target: When a service running as Local System connects with a NULL session, session security will be unavailable.

segment.source: Calls seeking encryption or signing will fail.
segment.target: Calls seeking encryption or signing will fail.

segment.source: This setting is more secure, but at the risk of degrading application incompatibility.
segment.target: This setting is more secure, but at the risk of degrading application incompatibility.

segment.source: Calls that are using the device identity instead of a NULL session will still have full use of session security.
segment.target: Calls that are using the device identity instead of a NULL session will still have full use of session security.

segment.source: Not defined.
segment.target: Not defined.

segment.source: When this policy is not defined, the default takes effect.
segment.target: When this policy is not defined, the default takes effect.

segment.source: This is Enabled for versions of the Windows operating system earlier than Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7, and it is Disabled otherwise.
segment.target: This is Enabled for versions of the Windows operating system earlier than Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7, and it is Disabled otherwise.

segment.source: Best practices
segment.target: Best practices

segment.source: When services connect with the device identity, signing and encryption are supported to provide data protection.
segment.target: When services connect with the device identity, signing and encryption are supported to provide data protection.

segment.source: When services connect with a NULL session, this level of data protection is not provided.
segment.target: When services connect with a NULL session, this level of data protection is not provided.

segment.source: However, you will need to evaluate your environment to determine the Windows operating system versions that you support.
segment.target: However, you will need to evaluate your environment to determine the Windows operating system versions that you support.

segment.source: If this policy is enabled, some services may not be able to authenticate.
segment.target: If this policy is enabled, some services may not be able to authenticate.

segment.source: This policy applies to Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista (SP1 and later).
segment.target: This policy applies to Windows Server 2008 and Windows Vista (SP1 and later).

segment.source: When your environment no longer requires support for Windows NT 4, this policy should be disabled.
segment.target: When your environment no longer requires support for Windows NT 4, this policy should be disabled.

segment.source: By default, it is disabled in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 and later.
segment.target: By default, it is disabled in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2 and later.

segment.source: Location
segment.target: Location

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesSecurity Options

segment.source: Default values
segment.target: Default values

segment.source: Server type or Group Policy Object (GPO)
segment.target: Server type or Group Policy Object (GPO)

segment.source: Default value
segment.target: Default value

segment.source: Default domain policy
segment.target: Default domain policy

segment.source: Not defined
segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Default domain controller policy
segment.target: Default domain controller policy

segment.source: Not defined
segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Stand-alone server default settings
segment.target: Stand-alone server default settings

segment.source: Not defined
segment.target: Not defined

segment.source: Domain controller effective default settings
segment.target: Domain controller effective default settings

segment.source: Not applicable
segment.target: Not applicable

segment.source: Member server effective default settings
segment.target: Member server effective default settings

segment.source: Not applicable
segment.target: Not applicable

segment.source: Effective GPO default settings on client computers
segment.target: Effective GPO default settings on client computers

segment.source: Not applicable
segment.target: Not applicable

segment.source: Security considerations
segment.target: Security considerations

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Vulnerability
segment.target: Vulnerability

segment.source: If this setting is Enabled, when a service connects with a NULL session, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection but allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.
segment.target: If this setting is Enabled, when a service connects with a NULL session, a system-generated session key is created, which provides no protection but allows applications to sign and encrypt data without errors.

segment.source: Data that is intended to be protected might be exposed.
segment.target: Data that is intended to be protected might be exposed.

segment.source: Countermeasure
segment.target: Countermeasure

segment.source: You can configure the computer to use the computer identity for Local System with the policy Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM.
segment.target: You can configure the computer to use the computer identity for Local System with the policy Network security: Allow Local System to use computer identity for NTLM.

segment.source: If that is not possible, this policy can be used to prevent data from being exposed in transit if it was protected with a well-known key.
segment.target: If that is not possible, this policy can be used to prevent data from being exposed in transit if it was protected with a well-known key.

segment.source: Potential impact
segment.target: Potential impact

segment.source: If you enable this policy, services that use NULL session with Local System could fail to authenticate because they will be prohibited from using signing and encryption.
segment.target: If you enable this policy, services that use NULL session with Local System could fail to authenticate because they will be prohibited from using signing and encryption.

segment.source: Related topics
segment.target: Related topics
